abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, with a likely sustainability and substantial
            institutional development impacts. The particularly strong
            performance by the Bank, during supervision, and the reforms
            achieved - exceeding expectations - is assessed as highly
            satisfactory, and, the Borrower's performance, given
            the successful privatization, is rated satisfactory. Key
            lessons address particularly, the potential difficulties in
            achieving institutional, or other types of reform, where a
            flexible supervision can make a difference: this project
            supervision missions opted for privatization, rather than
            restructuring parastatals, which evolved into profound, and
            sustainable results. In addition, experience in performance
            contracts for improving parastatal agencies efficiency, has
            demonstrated that incentives, and political will is often
            lacking in this type of reform, regardless of well conceived
            plans. But preservation of road assets should be focused on
            periodic maintenance, to avoid funding uneconomic projects;
            i.e., road investment plans should prioritize maintenance,
            ranking investments in accordance with the expected internal
            rate of return (IRR). However, the lack of structured, donor
            coordination proved vulnerable to the objections on road
            maintenance finance at the economic criteria standards
            agreed upon, a factor which would have greatly benefited
            funding. It is suggested that Sector Investment Programs be
            considered, if there is enough leverage to deepen
            institutional development reforms, and, provided performance
            indicators are linked to donor financing.
